section.title: Hashasli Ekmek Poppy-Seed Bread

para.emphasis: In Turkey, my husband's family makes this amazing bread called Hashasli Ekmek--a poppy seed bread, but better than any poppy seed bread that I ever had.

In the Eker family, recipes are passed from generation to generation by hands-on learning---no recipes. They adjust the ingredients based on time of year; temperature outside, humidity, and so on. I tried replicating this myself with mixed results. Then, I got the following wonderful recipe from a Turkish woman I met. The instructions for braiding the bread are a bit complicated; mine always comes out looking a bit messy, but always tastes great.
You might not pass a drug test if you eat too much Hashasli Ekmek.

listitem.para: Mix the poppy seeds, raisin, and half of the milk (1/2 cup) in a pot. Cook the mixture over very low heat until the seeds and raisin absorb all the milk (~10 min).
Cook the mixture over very low heat until the seeds and raisin absorb all the milk (~10 min).
While the poppy seeds are cooking, whisk corn starch, yolk and the other half of milk in a small bowl.
When the poppy seed mixture is ready, stir the egg yolk mixture into the pot and stir until thickened.
Remove filling from the heat; add butter, and stir well.

section.para: Reserve mixture to spread on dough when ready.

listitem.para: Mix all the ingredients for dough together. If the dough is sticky, add a little more flour.
Knead the dough, and leave to rise for 1 hour.
After an hour, knead dough again.
Oil a flat, circular tray to cook the bread.
Sprinkle a little flour on the counter and roll it out in a rectangle-like shape.
Spread poppy seed mixture on dough, and then scatter the raisins or currants on top.
Roll the dough tightly into a long tube.
With a sharp knife, slice the tube in half lengthwise.
Turn each half so that filling is facing up.
Wrap the dough in a spiral circle.

Braid the bread:
Lay each section on the counter with the filling facing up.
Pick up one piece of dough, and place it on top of the other section to form an X.
Lift one of the ends on the bottom piece of dough up and fold it over the top section of dough in a U shape. Do the same with the other bottom section so that you have two U-shaped sections joined in the middle, with 2 ends on each side.
Starting from the middle, braid the two ends on one side together.
Repeat on other side so that you have one long braided piece of dough.
On the circular pan, wrap the dough in a tight circle, pressing the two ends together to seal them.

section.para: Bake bread for 35 minutes, serve warm with black coffee to balance richness of bread.
